I tell my grandchildren to consider emigrating to a country with real health care for all and regulations that prevent banking crises--Canada comes to mind. I tell them there are many "great nations" and not to get caught up in jingoistic rhetoric.

Here is what I tell my nieces and nephews who have recently graduated. I tell them to be respectful of their elders. To find a mentor. To save for retirement starting with their first paycheck. I tell them to listen more and talk less when they start their first job even if they are bagging groceries at Whole Foods. There are new learning opportunities each and every day if we open ourselves to them. I tell them to not listen to all the negativity. We still live in the greatest country in the world. But I also tell them to travel far and often because the world is a miracle and people everywhere can teach us so much and broaden our views. I tell them that life really is all about the journey just like they say. But what makes the journey really fun are the people who travel with us, so choose wisely.

And then I help them write a killer resume. The practical is necessary as well.

[Part 1] I think that this analogy mischaracterizes the meaning and intent of Kierkegaard's use of pseudonyms and fictional personae, and does a disservice to the man and his thought.

Kierkegaard's role-playing and use of pen names was related (as Mr. Frank points out) to the problem of the inexpressibility of truth, as he conceived it. A sort of Hegelian, he believed (as Mr. Frank also points out) that the human experience of truth was essentially subjective; from a purely rational perspective, we seem to lack access to objective or transcendental truth, which seems not just valuable from an epistemological perspective, but also, to Kierkegaard and many others, to be the sort of truth that might bring peace to the unquiet human mind, akin to an authentic (and positive) "spiritual" experience.

And in fact, oddly enough, we may already possess it. Hegel argued that the dialectical interplay of individual subjectivities would eventually lead to an experience of that sort of truth; the apprehension of the dialectic process could itself be seen as a sort of transcendental, ahistorical consciousness, present in the mind of a historical being living in the midst of opposition and synthesis. This is the paradox which Kierkegaard talked about (and for which Christ is a metaphor, or vice versa), and which he struggled to accept and understand, and it's the paradox which he felt language - which would rather not say that something is, and is not - might not be able to express.

You know, I left out a whole other sense of the inexpressibility of truth in Kierkegaard's thought, that's also related to the idea of subjectivity...it has to do with the fact that we can't be certain that others' subjectivity is similar to ours in a sense that would permit of a shared language to describe it, and its truth - our only truth...in fact, we really can't be sure that other people aren't just leering marionettes shouting scripted lines at us; the only evidence we have that others exist - really - is the evidence of our senses, and that's hardly enough to found a belief in the existence of other subjectivities like ourselves on, is it?

Isn't this fun?

[Part 2] Today's "dog-whistle" communications, on the other hand, are intended to express thoughts which are merely potentially offensive or unpopular - but not paradoxical - via "code words", when the uncoded expression might have a negative impact on the popularity of the speaker and/or her positions. The unsaid, in these cases, is certainly sayable, when one feels that one is among like-minded individuals.

Kierkegaard's struggle to accept Hegelian positivism - the other leap, and more or less an analogy for his struggle with Christianity, and with optimism in general - was emotional and psychological, as well as intellectual, which is why many people (including myself) still find him to be sympathetic and compelling. Reading his work, it seems that his faith was intermittent at best; he never really seemed to be at peace, or to have found a place to rest. However, he didn't seem to want to hide this, or camouflage any heretical or scandalous ideas. He wished to express a paradoxical or ineffable state of mind; he used subversive or ironizing strategies of expression to do so. Today's "dog whistlers" just don't want to get caught soliciting votes from bigots.

Suggesting that there is any substantive similarity between his motives, his methods of communication, and their effects, and those of today's candidates and political consultants, does him a grave disservice, and dignifies the Karl Roves and Mark Penns of the world in a way which they will never deserve.

Bravo Professor Sharma--you finally understand at long last that not every problem in the Middle East is not Israel's fault and, yes, Israel has every right to defend itself from its aggressive neighbors.

Syria has used the Golan as early as 1948 to launch its first attempt to bring about Israel's demise during what came to be known as Israel's War of Independence. It then, between 1948 and 1967, used the Golan to bombard the collective and cooperative farming communities of the Galilee, and the fishermen in the Sea of Galilee. Then, again, in 1967 the Syrians, along with Egypt and Jordan, attempted to bring about Israel's demise through the use of the Golan during what came to be known as the June 1967 Six-Day War. It was then that Israel captured the Golan during that defensive war. But, Syria has not stopped there. In 1973 Syria, using the eastern parts of the Golan, launched, together with Egypt, the third attempt at Israel's demise. Would we expect any other country that has been the target of annihilation so many times to hand over the strategic piece of land used by the aggressor? And, if not, why expect the Jews to do so, as some here imply that Israel should do?

Sadly it is you who misleads with your historically inaccurate post:

The territory of the Golan Heights was controlled by the Ottomans in the 1860s and then settled by Jews (not Syrians) in the 1880s. In the 1920s, under the Mandate for Palestine, the territory was split between the British and French and became part of the French Mandate of Syria. When the French Mandate ended in 1944, the Golan Heights became part of the newly independent state of Syria. Following that, in the period between 1948 and 1967, the Syrians regularly fired artillery shells into and raided Israeli villages from their dominant positions on the Golan Heights. The UN turned a blind eye to the Syrian attacks (and its casualties), and finally, after continued shelling by the Syrians, the Israeli’s retaliated and took back the Golan in the 1967 Six Day War.

These answers are as close as Wikipedia. And if you’d like to reach even further back in history, according to the Bible, the Children of Israel conquered the Golan from the Amorites.
